Choices:  A: believe in god B: sun themselves C: eat hamburgers D: gain wealth E: eat plants<n><n>### Response:		<n>The correct answer:<n><n>A: believe in god<n><n>because they eat plants, not hamburgers.<n><n>### Input<n>How many different ways can the eight students on a soccer team be divided into four pairs that play defense together?<n><n><n>### Response<n>The correct answer: <n><n>B: 74<n><n>I did not include this answer, but should have stated the following:<n><n>If the defensive pairs are picked by dividing the students equally by pair, the number of student pairs is 4, the number of different pairs is 4! = 24.<n><n>If the defenders were picked by each player choosing the highest number they didn't choose for some other pair, then the number of pairs is 2 (all other choices), and the number of choices is 8! \* 7/2, making the answer 17560.<n><n>If the teams were picked from the top 8 players in skill by using a round-robin elimination method, then the number of students is 8, the number of possibilities for the first pair is 8!, and the next 7 pairs are determined by subtracting 1 from 8! each time, making the last pair 18!, so 6351360!

How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>### Input:What does reckless driving lead to on a person? Choices:  A: injuries B: fatigue C: traffic jams D: tired E: accidents<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>In answer to the question, input that I have 2 cards and Mara has 9 cards more, I would use the equation of 9(x) + 2 = 61. I would use 61 to find the total and have 6.1. Since there are two people who have a total of 6.1, I would answer C, and write that 6.1 lead to traffic jams.<n><n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Information:<n><n>#### Question:<n><n>**In a classroom, there is one book for every 6 students. Choices:  A: opened B: closed C: found at shower D: falling down E: locked<n><n>### Response:		E locked<n>### Reference Link: <https://leetcode.com/explore/interview/card/technical-screening-interviews-of-amazon/92/solution/divide-two-lists/1771/solution/><n><n>### Time:2min<n>```c++<n>class Solution<n>{<n>    public:<n>    int divideTwoLists(vector<int> &lefts, vector<int> &rights) {<n>        if (lefts.size() < 1) return 0;<n>        if (rights.size() <1) return 0;;<n>        int r=0, leftSum=0,rightSum=0;<n>        int temp=0;<n>        for(auto leftIdx: lefts )<n>        {<n>            if(leftIdx>0)<n>            {<n>                for(auto rightIdx: rights)<n>                {<n>                    if(rightIdx>leftIdx)<n>                    {<n>                       temp = leftIdx;<n>                    }<n>                    else<n>                    {<n>     <n>                        r++;<n>                        leftSum++;<n>                    }<n>                }<n>            }<n>        }<n>        r=lefts.size()+rightSum;<n>    <n>        return r-leftSum;<n>    }<n>};<n>```<n>

Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>### Input:Jan went to the auditorium and listened to the speech. Where might he be? Choices:  A: crowd B: high school C: city D: somewhere E: theater<n><n>### Response:		<n>D

Choices:  A: shelf B: cellar C: refrigerator D: cupboard E: grocery store<n><n>### Response:		<n>You went to the shelf, because all of those answers would be logical places to find canned foods.<n><n>### Input : Two years ago, James bought a television set worth $180. He will add to this sum the annual interest, compounded at six percent per year, if in each year after the end of two years he places the same amount of money in his bank account that he spent for the television. How much money will be in the bank account at the end of ten years, if he invests the same amount each year, and if at the end of each year he pays into the bank an amount that yields six percent interest?<n><n>### Response : <n>The answer is $3,006. Here's a breakdown of how I got that answer.<n><n>Year 1 $180<n>Year 2 $201<n>Year 3 $215<n>Year 4 $234<n>Year 5 $983<n>Year 6 $1,047<n>Year 7 $1,137<n>Year 8 $1,239<n>Year 9 $1,372<n>Year 10 $3,000<n><n>#### The two questions are very similar because you need to show profit after subtracting the initial investment.<n>

Input:The teams were competing evenly against one another, and what did spectators want  to find out? Choice: envy. We may ask the question: which team will have more spectators? Then, in either one of the teams, the spectators (audience) will most likely find out if that team will win in that sport.  We may answer the question, whether which team is the stronger.<n> <n>

deciding which career path to take?<n>To choose a career path, you might first consider interests, skills, or values.<n>What are two important pieces of information from which you can draw inferences about the career of a person whose business card you are examining?<n>They can be found on the business card, as well as the job category’s name printed on the business card.<n>What are the two major goals of the career planning process?<n>Understanding one’s wants and abilities are the two main goals in the career planning process.<n>What is the definition of an internship?<n>Internship is a period of training employed by an intern in a company in order to gain experience in their specified field.<n>What might someone do to prepare for their first day of work?<n>They must dress appropriately for work, arrive on time, and bring an appropriate lunch for the first day of work.<n>What might you need to consider before agreeing to an offer of employment?<n>You would need to consider the position, the benefits, the pay, the career, the commute, and the work environment.<n>What are the advantages of a job you can do online?<n>You work flexible hours, you get to schedule your own day, and you don't need to have a formal office.<n>What are the things you should consider while thinking about an ideal job?<n>You need to consider if the job is interesting, the work conditions, a comfortable work setting, a comfortable work hour, and a good pay.<n>What should you do if you are not sure which career path to take and you’re unhappy in your current job?<n>One should not rush into making their decision and should make a career test.<n>What could lead to an employer's deciding which applicants to invite for job interviews?<n>The employer will evaluate the applicants’ previous experience in working and will decide which are the most qualified candidates (the ones who are qualified for the job) according to their resume.<n>How is a person’s work experience often related to their career advancement?<n>Their work experience will determine how qualified they will be for the job which will determine their career advancement.<n>Which of the following might be a key component to the success of your business card?<n>The business card

En otras palabras, ¿qué número podría insertarse en el lugar de la raya para mostrar que el entero es igual? Is 3/1 the same as 1/3? Explain your answer.<n>### Respuesta 5: ¿6. Si 3/1 es igual a 1/3? Explica tu respuesta.<n>### Replies to other questions:<n><n>### Reply 6: 7. Name two fractions that when added to or subtracted from, result in the same amount. For example add 9/16 and 4/16. <n>### Respuesta #6: 7. Nombres de dos fracciones las cuales, cuando se suman o se restan, son iguales. Por ejemplo: 9/15 + 4/15.<n>### Explanation of other questions:<n><n>

How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>### Input:The woman experienced great joy, but despite that this was a what? Choices:  A: misery B: sadness C: bad time D: sorrow E: play time<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input: Misery<n>

The answer is try to learn more. This is because when one wants good grades  he or she should study more to get more knowledge in a field of study and understand things better. Therefore, one needs to put an effort to learn, but it also requires one to have the willingness and the effort to study hard.<n><n>### Input 2:A person wearing shorts, a long sleeve shirt and shoes spends a day at the beach. Therefore, the person would’ve lost cold protection.<n><n>### Output 2:The person has gained protection from cold.<n><n>### Response 2:The person would gain protection from cold temperatures. This is because wearing protective clothing for cold exposure prevents people from getting harmed by exposure to cold.<n><n>## Input 3:<n><n>### Question:What does one obtain from studying in school? I also love to travel so it'd be really fun if I would go to Canada but I will only go if I have a companion.  If I went without a companion it could be hard because I would be by myself and there are not as many tour groups or tours that go to the places I am interested in and I do not have enough money to pay for both trips. I have enough money between me and my parents which would be $750 and I need an additional $500 because I would still need to pay for tours or to go on a tour with someone. What is the total amount of money that I should save for my Canada vacation?<n><n>### Response The total amount of money that you should save for your Canada vacation is 2,000

If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>### Input:You are seeking to provide yourself what when you're applying for a job? Choices:  A: work B: employment C: income D: hope E: offer<n><n>### Response:		Choice: E<n><n><n>

How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>### Input:Where can someone purchase a contraceptive device without a prescription? He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>### Input:If you're standing in line and the line isn't moving what might you feel? Below is the schema describing the format of the data.<n><n>| Student ID<n>----|<n> | Last name<n>----|<n> | First name<n>----|<n>Major|<n>----|<n> | Number of classes taken|<n>----|<n><n>###  Schema:<n>The `student` table contains three columns: `student_id`, `first_name`, and `last_name`. The `major` table contains two columns, `major_id` and `number_of_classes`.<n><n>### Challenge inputs:<n><n>1. `student_id = 16`<n>2. `major = `electrical_engineering`<n>3. `number_of_courses = 4`<n>```javascript<n>create table student as (<n>  student_id int<n>, first_name varchar(20)<n>, last_name varchar(25)<n>, major varchar(25) as 'electrical_engineering'<n>, number_of_courses int<n>);<n><n>-- insert information for student id 16<n>update student set student_id = 1, first_name = 'Mike', last_name = 'Ogilvy', major = 'computer_science', number_of_cources = 1<n>;<n>update student set student = 2, first_name = last_name = 'Farnsworth', major = 'electrical_engineer'<n>;<n>-- run the report<n>select * from student;<n>```<n><n>### Challenge response:<n><n>1. If the `student_id` is `16`<n>    ```javascript<n>    select student.first_name + " " + student.las_name<n>    from student<n>    where student.student_id = 7;<n>    ```<n>2. Choices:  A: building B: office C: library D: table E: bathtub<n><n>### Response:		A is correct.<n><n>We know that Janet has 9 more cards than Brenda. We know from the wording that Mara has "twice as many cards" as Janet, which means Mara has 2 more cards. That means Janet has 11 cards, and Brenda has 12 cards. That means there are 21 cards in all.<n><n>| Input      | Input        | Output            | Solution   |<n>| ---------- | ------------- | ------------------ | :-------- |<n>| Pete      | Houston       | 50                | 50        |<n>| Houston    | Houston       | 45                 | 95        |<n>| Houston     | garage       | 50                 | 100       |<n>| garage     | post office | 40                  | 40        |<n><n>We start with our inputs and add them together with the word "in all". We have 50 + 45 + 50 + 35 = 170.<n><n>To get the output we subtract 35 (the number of gallons the bus holds) from 50 (the distance the bus traveled). It is the 2 trips Pete made plus the distance of 20 blocks to get to the post office.<n><n>| Input       | Input        | Output         | Solution    |<n>| ----------- | ------------- | --------------- | :---------- |<n>| 4.5        | gallons       | pint           |  pints       |<n>| 3         | thermoses     | pint            |  pints       ||<n>| 6         | pints         | quart           |  quarts       ||<n><n>So, we know both Genevieve and her friend have 4 quarters and that they both have 4. The only case is for their 3 thermoses, but that must be wrong because Genevieve's friend has twice as many quarts as Genevieve. But Genevieve has twice as many quarters as her friend! Thus, both have an extra quart of coffee.<n><n>| Input         | Input        | Output        | Solution     |<n>| ------------- | ------------- | ------------    | :--------- |<n>| 10           | Berries        | 18             | 18         |

How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>### Input:What is a person likely to feel when they are abandoned by everyone after they stop being married to someone else? Choices:  A: grief B: solo C: isolation D: pleasure E: happiness<n><n>### Response:		<n>1.	Abandonment is an emotion that occurs when you feel deserted when there's someone who doesn't care for you or love you. This feeling usually comes from fear or jealousy about another person getting your partner's or spouse's full attention.<n><n>2.	Abandonment involves feelings of being alone, lonely or rejected by someone who has been essential to you. When this happens you feel like people don't care about you or they’ve already left you behind.<n><n>### What is the most important information you can extract from these directions?<n><n>-	The number of cards that each person in the room has.<n><n>-	The answer to the question.<n><n>## What is the next step in the task?<n><n>The next step is to do the same steps in the previous question with the answers given above.<n><n>## Which step would it be helpful to re-read instructions?<n><n>Read the question.<n><n>How could you tell if you chose a good answer?<n><n>If you chose the answer, the problem would say, "B".<n><n>## What are some examples of what could go wrong if the task is handled incorrectly?<n><n>If there is a calculation problem, it would show "Incorrect".<n>

Choices:  A: understand B: were there C: ignorance D: in-between E: ignorant<n><n>### Response:		<n>```python<n>x=str(input)<n>s=len(x)<n>answer=''<n>for i in range(s):<n>    answer += x[i]<n><n>for n in range(2,s-13,6):<n>    z=n+2<n>    k=int(n/float(n)/float(10))+1<n><n>    y=[z*int(k)]<n>    print(y)<n>```<n><n>### Expected output:<n>The sum of all numbers from 1 to 31 is shown in the output.<n>```python<n>78<n>```

Choices:  A: dry hair B: spreading C: blowing hard D: change direction E: wave wheat<n><n>### Response:		I think the best answer is choice "A:dry hair" because shingles are dry.<n><n>### Input<n>### Demonstion<n>A: I think the best answer is d: change direction because the wind usually has a certain direction.<n><n>### Response<n>I think that the wind is not blowing the leaf so i'll say:<n><n>### Demostration<n>A: This is the best answer<n>B: The corn is the best answer<n>C: It is not the best answer<n>D: I think the best Answer is...<n>E: I think the best one is...<n><n><n>### Demosration<n>A: i think the best answer is A: d: change direction because it is not blowing the leaves.<n><n>### Problem Description:<n>```<n>Demonstration:<n><n>Input: On November 6,1617, the group of Pilgrims that was landing in Massachusetts was on their first Thanksgiving dinner. The Pilgrims were in the Plymouth Rock area. They were celebrating the thanksgiving dinner with local Native Americans. They both enjoyed the meal. The people brought all the food as a big contribution to the meal. Some examples that were brought to the dinner were bread, fish, corn, and deer. There were 90 people in total that were celebrating their first thanksgiving dinner. The dinner was a three-day event. The Pilgrims and the Natives were in peace at the dinner. They became friends by the end of the day. On the second day, they were still in peace. The same amount of people decided to go to a second day of thanksgiving dinner. At the second day of the dinner, the Pilgrims and Natives gave each other different food. The Natives gave them popcorn, wild turkeys, eel, duck, clams, crabs, lobsters, oysters, sturgeon, corn, beans, gourds, watermelon, and sunflower. It was a very big celebration and everyone was happy about it.<n>```<n><n>### Instuction:On November 6,1517, the group ( of 90) was landing in Massachusetts. The group was celebrating their first Thanksgiving with the local Natives. They both enjoyed the dinner. They

The 5th pair finished the race 1.5 minutes before the second pair. How long did it take the last man to finish the race?<n><n>### Response<n>25<n><n>### InputChoices:<n><n>D<n><n>### ResponseChoices:<n><n>A<n><n>## Solution:<n><n>### Instructions:How many letters are in this word?<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>### Constraints:<n><n>### Input Choices:<n><n>### Response Choices:<n><n>```<n>22<n>```<n><n>### Conclusion<n><n>### Solution:<n><n>```solution<n>int n = 3;<n>int[] s = new int[9];<n>for (int i = 0; i < 9; i++) {<n>	s[i] = s[i - 1];<n>}<n>if (n > 5) {<n>	s[0] = 6;<n>}<n>if (s[0] > 1) {<n>	for (int i = s[0]-1; i > 2; i--) {<n>		s[i] -= 1;<n>	}<n>}<n>System.out.println(s[n]);<n>s[n] += 7;<n>while (s[n] > 1)<n>	System.out.println("s[" + n + "] = " + s[n] + " " + s[n - 1]);<n>System.out.print("s = ");<n>for (int i : s)<n>	System.print(i + " ");<n>```<n><n>## Tasks:<n><n>### Task 1<n><n>Write a program that prints the numbers of letters in the given word.<n><n>### Task2<n><n>Write a program similar to that of Task 1 but with a different type of input.<n><n>### Example<n><n>```java<n>import javax.print.attribute.BasicAttribute;<n>import javax.print.*;<n>import java.io.*;<n><n>class TextStreamNameJob<n>{<n>    private PrintService printservice;<n>    private PrintRequestAttributes printRequestAttributes;<n>    private PrintDialog printDialog;<n>    private PrintJob printJob

Choices:  A: eat grass B: play C: kept in stables D: dominated E: drink coffee<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>A, the answer is eating grass<n>

Write another program that inputs two strings, the first length of both strings, and an expression. The task is to compare the strings using the expression.<n>2. If the strings do not compare, explain why. In cases where the strings do compare, you must write a statement declaring whether the strings compare or do not compare. Hint: you don't need to include an explanation.<n>3. If the strings have the same length, you can simply write if(string1 == string2) then … end. If they are not the same length, you must consider the length of each string (their first lengths) and apply the expression as a condition for comparing the strings.<n>4. The expression is not equal to, is equal to, greater than, less than:<n>- is not equal to: string1!= string2<n>- equal to: string1 == string2<n>- greater than: string1 > string2<n>- less than: string1 < string2<n>5. Write a program to input a sequence of numbers.  Use the first number as a pivot number.  Separately sum all of the numbers before the pivot number, divide the sum by 2, round the number down to the nearest whole number, and assign it to variable A. Use the pivot number as a second pivot. Separately sum all the numbers after the pivot number, divide by 5, round the number down, and assign it to a variable B.<n><n>6. Print A - B.<n><n>7. Write a program that accepts a string, prints out all the words in that string (capitalized), and separates them with commas.<n><n>8. If another 3 students are added, how much change will they get back? Choices: A: $0.05 B: $0.25 C: $0.50 D: $0.75<n><n>### Response1: $0.00<n><n>### Exlanation:The students in total had $100 which was 75 cents each so to make it $100 again it needs to be 75 cents times 12 which is $8.75 which brings the total to $100 (75 cents x 12 = $8.75)<n><n>### Input2:The average rainfall in Seattle for February is 10.7 inches. For example: The number 6 is evenly divided by 5, the remainder is 1. Therefore 6 divided by 5 is 6/5=1 remainder 1. If instead 7 divided by 5 the result will be 7/5=1. He'll use an old machine to teach kids. It counts and prints in steps of 1. (Every 2 counts = 1 print). How many kids can use it in one hour?<n><n>### Response to Instructions and Demonstration:If a kid counts 6, it prints 2. If a kid counts 6 more it prints 11. If he counts 6 again he will have counted 15. It will print 1. If the kid counts 7 it prints 3. If he counts 7 again he will have counted a total of 14. If the kid counts until he reaches 20, how many kids is he?<n><n>### Input and Demonstration Answer:<n>The number of kids is 26<n><n>### Response Answer:<n>The number is 26<n>

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>### Input:What past time are people engaged in when they are traveling along liquid? Choices:  A: zoo B: workplace C: sky D: new york city E: many places<n><n>### Response:		If you want to see animals in a large northeelast city, you can easily see them in a zoo, a workplace, the sky and new york city. It is not necessarily true that you cannot see animals in many places.<n><n>### Input 2:What are things that we will not find in a large northeast city? The city is not a big box store and there will never be a pet shop or ant farm inside of it.<n><n>### Response 2:The things that we will never find in a large northeast city are a big box store, pet shop and an ant farm there. There will be neither a big box store nor a pet shop nor an ant farm inside a large northeaster city, the city is not.<n><n>### Answer Key:Choices A C and E would be correct but A would be the most correct.<n><n>### Direction:The task below asks for the correct mathematical answer to a situation. Write a complete sentence to describe what the answer should be and a complete sentence that shows your mathematical solution.<n><n>### Example:<n><n>Input:Amy buys milk every day at the grocery store, where a half gallon costs $1.75 and a whole gallon costs $3.50. She has $78 in her pocket. How many half gallons of milk can Amy buy?<n><n>Answer: 4<n><n>### Solution<n><n><n>Amy buys milk on a daily basis. Amy buys milk each day at the groceree where a half gallon has a price of $1.75, while a whole gallon costs at $3.50 a glass. Amy has $78 in cash. How many half gallon glasses of milk can Amy buy on a daily basis? Because half gallon of milk is equal to two pints, Amy can buy $2.95 in half gallon glasses in every day. On a daily basis, Amy can buy $5.90 in pints of milk. Her daily earnings can be determined by multiplying each pints by six. At first, we know that half gallon is equal to two pins. $1.75 for half a gallon means $1.75 per pint. $1.72 multiplied by two equals to $3.44, which means she can buy $3.4

She made two times as many jelly beans as Ann. Ann made 9 jelly beans. What was the difference between Ann's total of jelly beans and Mary's double their total?<n><n>### Answer<n>  A- 7<n>  B- 8<n>  C- 9<n>  D- 12<n><n>### Instructios: Answert the following multiple choice question <n><n>### Input  <n><n>Nick bought two times as many eggs as Danny, and four times as many peaches as Chelsea. If he had two bananas and four apples, how many pieces of fruit did he buy, all together? (a. 24 b. 40 c 20, d. 48, e. 12, f. 10, g. 6<n><n>## I found this problem to be interesting because I never knew how different math problems could be answered in so many ways. It taught me a lot about word problems and when I look at a word problem now it will be easier to understand.<n><n>### I can use these concepts to solve the following 4 different problems<n><n>###1. What is 12 x 9 in a problem.<n><n>###2. What is the difference between 12 x 8 and 8 x 12.<n><n>###3. What is the difference if you multiply 20 by 8.<n><n>###4.  What is the difference between multiplying 10 by 9 or 9 by 10.<n>

One day, he found a nice, round, red and blue rock; and he took it home to share with his wife.  When he got home, his wife, who was a homely little lobster with a flat body, was standing in the doorway looking very much surprised and happy. The little lobster handed her the rock. "This is for you," he said, "now isn't that something?" "What's that?" asked his surprised wife, "something?" The little lobster was so happy he said, "why, it's a rock!" "A rock?" "Yes, a rock." He pulled out another rock from under the potato in which he lived. "Here's another for you, my lovely little wife." "A rock?" said the wife. "What good is a rock?" The little lobstress said to herself, "I really must help myself get out of this mess. It isn't a nice thing to be married to a lobster, but it's the only one I can get." The next day she found a nice, smooth, round, white-spotted rock. "This one's for you," she shouted happily to her lobster husband. He was so surprised he had to turn over on his back. When he couldn't see her any more, she crawled off. By dawn, she had crawled up the steps to the kitchen sink, and she had slipped neatly under the sink cabinet. Before long, she worked her way out of the sink and up to the porch. <n><n>She scurried along up the steps to the house and into her new home. She soon found a good hiding place behind the stove. There she stayed for three days. The little lobstrous never missed her as she crawled away. He lived happily in the dark under the potato until he was caught by a lobster fisherman. "You shouldn't marry a lobster; there

Even in a full immersion environment you're likely to make mistakes, mistakes will cause misinterpretation, which will be uncomfortable, which will cause what?, Choices:  A: better communication B: overthinking C: frustration D: misunderstandings E: headaches<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>### Explanation:<n>Language learning is a complicated and daunting task. Even in a fully immersive environment, people will make mistakes. These mistakes can lead to misinterpretation that makes the learner more uncomfortable, and that uncomfortable feeling can further cause the student to overthink everything. By overthinking everything the person feels more uncomfortable and starts making more mistakes. This creates a cycle that can be uncomfortable and frustrating for the learner.<n><n>

How many berries does it eat?<n><n>### Demand:<n>### The value of a house doubles every 7 years<n><n>### Demands<n>### If a house costs 100 pound sterling, how much a house will cost with a doubling effect?<n><n>  | <n><n>#<n><n># If the answer for question 8 was 40, would it still be correct with a doubling effect of 7 years?<n>If so, how much will it cost after 7 years?<n><n>### Recommendations:<n><n>If the answer was 40, it should not be too difficult to increase it to over $1,000,000, considering the doubling fact.<n><n>### Response from James: <n>I will say that that's not the case. I would recommend not to do that. Let me explain by giving you more details. First, the 7 years isn't a doubling effect. Doubling effects double a number after a certain time. So the seven years doesn't mean the value will double after seven years, but after seven years, the value is double or even triple. Since it is a doubling effect, I don't think the number $40M is correct.<n>### Response to James:<n>My suggestion would be, instead of answering every questions, try to read the whole question in the first place. Choices:  A: alive B: health C: fun D: playing dead E: black<n><n>### Response:		A is the correct answer<n><n>### Output:<n>Output:<n>The correct answer is: A.<n>   <n>> ```python<n>> print(the_answer) #will return to the user.<n>> ```<n><n>### Instructions:<n>If a certain input is answered incorrectly, the program needs to return one of the input options not selected in the input.<n><n>### Test Case:<n>For example, if someone answered D, Output should display C.<n><n>### Note:<n>You should use a nested for loop to print them.<n><n>### Run:<n>```python<n>the_answer = ""<n>correctanswer = the_answer<n><n>a= "alive" <n>b= "black"<n>c= "health"<n>d= "fun"<n>e= "playing dead"<n><n>k= 0<n>while k < len(correctanswer)<n>    #print(k.index(c)) #outputs index of the user's input answer.<n>    if k.index(c) == k.index(the_answer):<n>        <n>        k+= 1<n>        print(c)<n>        k+= 2<n>        print(d)<n>        #break<n>        correctanswer="C"<n>        the_answer = "A"<n><n>    <n>    elif k.index(c)> k.index(theanswer):<n>        <n>         correctanswer= " A "<n>        # break<n>        print("the answer is incorrect")<n>        #outputs an index where the user's answer is incorrect.<n>         the_answer = "C"<n><n>    else:<n>         correctanswer="B"<n>        the_an = "F"<n><n>print(" the answer is correct")<n>    <n>```<n><n>### Outputs the result:<n><n>### Instructor will grade your submission.<n><n>### Submit response here to complete the task.<n><n>### Please provide feedback if you need it.<n><n>### Congratulations! You completed the task.<n>

If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>### Input:The skin was cut while chopping onions, where was this skin likely cut? Without hands, you can't punch at all.<n>```<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Instructions:<n>Input: John was punching and hitting at the wall but was only able to bruise his fists. This was bad. He would be unable to lift his tools if he injured his? Choices: A: anger B: hostility C: nose D: hands E: fists<n><n>## Answer:<n>John punched the wall with clenched fists, causing bruises to his fingers and knuckles.<n><n>### Input<n>Input: Tina's car got a flat tire. Finally, Tina paid an extra $49 for tire repair.  After all these, Tina was left with $65.   How much did the tire cost Tina?<n>Answer: $85<n><n>### Input - Demonstration<n>Tina has a flat tire. The garage charges her for the tire repair. The cost of her oil change. She then pays the repair costs.<n><n>### Answer<n>Tina had spent $150. A savings account interest rate amounted to $10. After all deductions, John had $500 left in the bank.<n><n>### Response - Instructions:<n>When you add percentages, you can only add 100%. 50% of 100 is 50. 50% of what is 50?

The only way to move from one room to another is through the ventilation.<n><n>You will now be presented with several houses, each with a possible escape route. The only way out is by climbing out a window or crawling through an opening in the foundation.<n><n>How do you escape?<n><n>### Response<n><n>From the attic at all times, you should crawl until you get out<n><n><n>### Input 2:<n>You woke up inside a cave. You are facing the entrance. There is a path going from that point forward, and that path goes to a dead-end. The path is visible from where you are lying, but you are afraid to go because some wild beasts may be lurking ahead. Where should you go to be safe?<n><n>### Question:<n><n>A: straight ahead B: go into the depths of the cave C: go to the middle of the path and back-track D: turn to the right E: go to the dead-end and then continue into the cave<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>A<n>### Justification:<n><n>You should choose choice A because it is the only path that is visible. Wild beast may be there, but it will not be able to find you or catch you because it cannot move from the middle of the cave into the dead-end.<n><n><n><n><n><n>

It's a 200 mile trail, and takes about a month to hike." Which distance is equal to the total length of the Appalachian trail? <n><n>### Response:"1,000 miles"  <n><n>### Explination:<n>Distance from New York City to Atlanta is 1,000 Miles. The distance from New York City to Birmingham is 750 miles. So the second is the distance from birmingham to Atlanta, which is total of 1,00 miles.<n><n>### INPUT: Choose the correct answer.<n><n>- 24 <n><n>- 8 <n><n>- 1 <n><n>- 6 <n><n>- 4 <n><n>- More than 498 miles<n><n>- Less than 498<n><n>- 358 miles<n><n>- 296 minutes or 5 hours<n><n>- 28 pages<n><n>### RESPONSE:"5 hours"<n><n>### EXPLANATION:<n>The distance from one point to the other is 28 miles which is 50 miles. So 50/50 = 1<n>

How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>### Input:John and Jane were a couple. The highest number of students came from two schools, and each school has students with 25 or more questions right. The school with the most students that could have taken the tests in 2013 has twice as many students who could take tests in 2020 than the school with the least students who could take tests. Which two schools have 100 students or more that were able to take tests?<n>Answer: A: St. Mark's School, C: Harvard University, D: Emerson College, E: Tufts University, F: Wellesley College<n><n>### Response<n>Response: D: (90-86)*2 = 98 - B and A both have 24+ students not E and F both have 17+ students and all are schools.<n><n>### Solution: The solution to this task is available to approved users. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>### Input:What does a chef do when working in the evening? How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>### Input:Where would you sit in a chair to watch four-legged animals complete? Choices:  A: bookstore B: house C: race track D: friend's house E: building<n><n>### Response:		<n>E<n><n>### Reference:<n>You don’t have to memorize these lines as I will give it to you in class.<n><n>## Solution:<n><n>1. Input: Janet has 1 times as many cards as Brenda. Brenda has 2 times as many cards as Mara. Mara has 4 times as many cards as Jan. Jan has 9 cards more cards than Brenda. Mar has twice as many cards than Janet. How many card do they all have?<n><n>```python<n>ans = 211 <n>```<n><n>2. Input: Pete walked 2 blocks from his house to a bus garage in Houston to take a bus. He rode the bus for 20 blocks to reach to post office in Montgomery to get a stamps. Later, Pete comes back the same way. His total distance is 50 blocks.<n><n>```python<n>import math<n>dist = 0<n><n># First block<n>dist = dist + 2<n><n># Bus<n>dist = dist +20<n># Travel Distance in the Bus<n><n>distance +=20<n><n># Post Office Distance<n>distance = distance + 20<n><n># Distance to Post Office from bus Depot to Home <n><n>totaldistance = distance + dist<n>```<n><n>3.Input: In a class room there are blue chairs green chairs, and wite chairs. There are ten blue chairs. The gregreen chairs are 3times more chairs as the blue chairs. They are more than the blue chairs but less than 15 chairs. How many chairs in class room.<n><n>```python <n>  <n>import math<n>nTotal = 0<n><n>for i in range(10):<n>    # Blue Chair<n>    if i == 1:<n>        nTotal = nTotal +1<n>        continue<n><n>    # Total seats <n>    nTotal = nTotal - 1<n><n>    # Green chairs <n>    if (i > 10 and i < 20):<n>        nTotal = (nTotal + 1) - 1<n>    # White seats<n>    if (i >= 20 and i < 30):<n>        n = nTotal + 1<n>        break<n>```<n><n><n>4. Input: Alannah,  Beatrix

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>### Input:The woman picked from an apple tree while surrounded by other trees, where was she? Choices:  A: illinois B: woods C: new york D: indiana E: farmer's market<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Input : Jane is twice as old as her sister. Her sister has a pet mouse. How old is Jane? After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>### Input:The whole family was playing cards, they were full of joy and what? Choices:  A: sadness B: happiness C: amusement D: losing money E: anger<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>The whole family was playing card, choices of losing money and amusement.<n><n>### Input (Example):<n>Janet has 9 cards mor than brenda. Mara has two as many as janet. How many card do they have all if mara has four than 150.<n><n>### Output:<n>output should have the right answer and also the number of cards.<n>For example: Janet has 20 cards, Brenda has 8 cards, Mara has 16 cards, Janet has 34 cards, Brenda has - 9 cards, Mara has - 36 cards. Total cards they have 51 cards.<n>The output should be 211.<n><n>### Solution:<n>Let say Janet has n cards and brenda has m cards. Let's assume the cards are n and m positive integers.<n><n>Example Janet and brenda each have 5 cards.<n><n>Janet has 5, in two ways:<n><n>1)<n>n + 5 <n><n>2)<n>5 + n<n><n>We get n = 6 <n><n>The whole family is playing cards, choices of losing money a<n>nd amusement, Mara has 4 10 more than 150, n = 4 in 2 ways:<n><n>1)(4 + 150)<n><n>2)<n>150 + 4<n><n>Mara has 3 less than 157. Janet has - 5 less than brenda;<n><n>(157 - 3) + ( -5)<n><n>n + m<n><n>(m + n) - 1<n><n>The whole family has 211 cards total.<n>

How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>### Input:How can you get in shape if there is no land nearby? Choices:  A: swim B: jog C: excercise D: work out E: rock climb<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>### Instructions: If a group of kids at recess were drawing cards from a deck consisting of hearts, clubs, diamonds, and spades, what is the probability of drawing 2 spades and 2 diamonds, if the probability for each card is 4/13?<n><n>### Demostration: There is a 4/16 possibility of drawing the first card (one of hearts, clubs, or diamonds) when the deck is shuffled, so there is a 4/4 * 4/16 = 4/16 probability of first drawing a heart. The second card can be either a spade (5/16 possibility or a diamond (7/16 possibility. The combination of those possibilities is 4/16 + 5/16 + 7/16 = 16/16. The possibility of those two cards being hearts, spades, or diamonds is 4/126, so we multiply the first 16/126 by 4/12-1, finding 4/4 *16/12 = 4/12.<n><n>### Input :The probability of getting either an ace or a king is<n><n>Answer: 4/52 - 3/51 = 9/103<n><n>### Instructins: If you drew 3 cards in a row without replacement starting from the 11th card and counting down toward 1, what are the chances of getting 3 kings first?<n><n>### Demo: The probability of drawing the first card as a king is<n><n>### Input<n>answer:<n>The probability of drawing the first two cards as king:<n>answer:<n>The possibility of drawing the first 3 cards as kings is: <n><n>### Instuctins : <n>What is the expected number of cards that need to be drawn until 3 Kings are found?<n><n>### Display: P(k) is the expected number of draws: 14!/(4!3*5*6*7!) * 5/13 = 5/5 * 8/9 = 40/81<n><n><n><n><n>### Input (Directions):You have 5 cards, each with a number from 1 through 8 on the

This app can work like this: A user enters a phrase containing a grammatical error. The program then returns a list of possible answers, each of which replaces the grammatical error in the input phrase. For example, if the user enters "I can run faster" and the program returns "I can run fter," then "I can run faster", the program has correctly detected a run-on sentence and suggested the correct punctuation for it.<n><n>### Deliverable:<n>Deliver a program that accepts a sentence containing a grammar error, returns a list of correct grammatically-correct replacements for the error, and prints the name of the choice that the user selected.<n><n>### Note<n>As a reminder, the program may be a Java program written and run on the Blackboard.<n><n>#<n># Output:<n>The following is a sample output:<n>Sample Output<n><n>### Instructon:<n>Enter an English phrase containing a grammatcal error!<n>Sample Input<n>I want to read more books<n><n>### Example Output<n>Give the English book to your teacher?<n>Give you English books your teacher?<n>Grade my English homework?<n>English homework grade my?<n><n>#<n># Notes<n>

How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>### Input:When they got out of the car in the mountains he felt like he was breathing fresh air for the first time, he began to do what to enjoy it more? Choices:  A: living B: feeling good C: hyperventilate D: look around E: breathe deeply<n><n>### Response:		When they got out of the Car in the mountains He felt like they were breathing fresh air for first time, He began to breathe in and out deeply.<n>

Choices:  A: exercise B: moving forward C: feet D: blisters E: locomotion<n><n>### Response:		<n>Exercising, moving forward, and blisters are all verbs for walking, while feet and locomotion are nouns for walking.<n><n>### Input:[4, 2, 6, 5] What is the median of the following data? <n><n>### Demostration:<n>4 + 6 + 2 = 12 > 2 + 5 = 7. <n><n>### Response:[2, 6,4]<n><n>### Input:{5,12,8,3,4} What is the median of this list of numbers?  <n><n>### Demosration:<n>12 = 5<n>5 + 3 + 4 + 8 + 12 / 5 * 4 + 4 = 8  = 3<n>5 * 4 + (8 + 4) = 19 > (5 + 8) * 4 = 23<n>23 > 19<n>6 < 5 <n><n>### Input :In a survey, 41% of teens in Minnesota like pizza, 26% of teens in New York like pizza, and 1% of teens across the country like pizza. What percent of the 850 teens across the country who were surveyed liked pizza?<n>In a survey, 21% of teens like pizza across the country<n>26 + 41 - 1 / 21 = 50%<n><n>### Input In 1998, 2500 high school students were surveyed about their college choice. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>### Input:Having a car in the city seemed to be more trouble than it was worth, the man still had to walk to and from the what after commuting? Choices:  A: driveway B: the event C: scrap heap D: parking garage E: repair shop<n><n>### Response:		The response should be the letter D.<n><n>### Input：Jennifer has 80 books of her own to read and 6 more books than her brother. Her mother gives her 12 books and gives her brother 5 fewer books than she gave her. If she gives her brother another 3 books and he gives her 2 fewer books than she gave him, how many books will be left?<n><n>### Response：The response should be the letter E.<n><n>

Janet has 9 more than Brenda. So Mara has 2x as many as Brenda.<n>But Brenda has 5 less than Janet. So Maras cards must be:<n><n>    cards = 2x(40) - 5 = 220<n><n>    so we have Maras have 220 cards<n><n><n>### Task:<n>In this assignment, you will write and submit a Word document answering the questions below.<n><n>

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>### Input:What might someone do who is having fun? It can be hard to make time to go to the doctor and get an appointment because they are usually booked up months in advance. It's also hard to wait in the doctor's office because people might be late or have other things going on during their day, such as work or school. It's important to think about the doctor before you go to their office because it might take a lot longer than you think.<n><n><n><n><n><n>

If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon. Choices:  A: from the sky B: map C: cross counties by car D: country E: michigan<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### The following question requires you to use complete sentences describing the solution to the coding problem.<n><n>### Describe how these steps help you determine the total numbers of chairs, and the total number of pints of coffee.<n><n>### Step One:<n>I first used what was known to write a formula.<n><n>### Total Chairs=Blue chairs+Green chairs+White chairs<n><n>### Step Two:<n><n>Then I added each number which represents it in the formula.<n><n>## Step Three:<n>Finally I calculated the answer.<n><n>### The Total Chairs=10+3(blue chairs)<n><n>### Step Four:<n>I continued adding each number.<n><n>### To answer the question, I used what I previously known.<n><n>### I added each number together to get the final answer.<n><n>## The following question requires you write a sequence of steps to solve the problem.<n><n>## The total servings =306<n><n>```JavaScript<n>var carrot = 4<n>var corn = 5<n>var greenbean= 5<n>var total= 306<n>var servings=0<n>for (;servings<total;){<n>//first I multiplied the plant with the carrot by carrot.<n>carrot*carrot<n>//then I multiplied corn with the carrot by corn<n>corn*corn<n>//finally I Multiplied the greenbean.<n>// I used my formula to write the rest.<n>for (var d=d;servings<total+d+5*servings;){<n>console.log(servings)<n>console.log('the servings is '+servings)<n>servings=servings+5<n>}<n>}<n> //if I wanted to make the servings 50 servings I could have done so.<n>```<n><n>## The following problem requires you write a series of steps to solve the given problem.<n><n>## Input: Jericho has $10 and Annika, Manny, and Voltaire owe him the following: Voltaire $14, Annika $36, and Manny $24. Choices:  A: grocery store B: grocery bag C: restaurants D: farmer's market E: bushel basket<n><n>### Response:		<n>The options that do not apply to carrying potatoes home is A and E. <n><n>Input: You eat 33 potatoes when you eat at the store, so what is one?  Choices: A: 10 B: 11 C: 15 D: 20 E: 32<n><n>Response:<n>The answer choice that does not apply to eating potatoes is A(10).<n><n>### Response to this error<n>In this sentence (and the solution), you did not specify that you wanted the answers that were **not compatible** to the input, but instead you provided answers that were all compatible.<n><n>```python<n># What I attempted.<n>a = "Janet has 9 cards less than Brenda.  Mara has two as many cards as Janets.  How many cards do they all have in all if  Mara has 4 cards less than sixty?"<n># How it should be answered.<n>a = "Mara's cards total 39 less than sixty cards.  Janet total cards plus Brendas.  Both cards total are twice Janet's cards plus Brendas."<n>```<n><n>### Response<n>Here, I have shown that it is easy to go from a number sentence to a subtraction expression.

If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>### Input:Where do almost all people live? Choices:  A: confusion B: complications C: riot D: arrest E: protests<n><n>### Response:		D.<n><n>### Answer:D.<n><n><n>```<n>var i = 2<n>while ( i < 10 ) {    //  while(i < 10)<n>    console.log("i:", i)<n>    if (  i % 3 === 0 &&  i % 5 === 0  ){<n>      i = i + 1<n>      console.log("i + 1:", i)<n>      break<n>    } else {<n>      i = i ++<n>    }<n>  }<n>```<n><n>`while ( i < 9 )` would also execute.<n><n>### Explanation:The `while` statement will loop through the code inside it when the condition is met. It’s essentially like a conditional `for` loop. We break this when the condition is met, and will only run once more if the condition is not met.<n>

A thermometer will sometimes read 4 degrees colder than the actual temperature. In what range of temperatures did the thermometer read 4 degrees coldest at 11:30 am on this day?<n><n>### Response : <n>11 degrees Celsius (11-10 is 1)<n><n>To help students remember that a negative number is opposite of a positive number, you often have students draw a line between two numbers, including zero, to see how they compare. On a number line, draw two opposite lines as shown below:<n><n>>![alt text](https://d33wubrfki7tvt.cloudfront.net/thumbs/0/0/e/0/0/00e0824c97e5f31aac14141eb5fd3ec3ee7718f8_thumb.png "Number Line")<n><n>|          -1          |  1          |     2        |<n>| ------------------ | ------------- | ------------- |<n>|           -1          |            1         |<n>|             -3        |            1       |<n>|             -4        |          5         |<n>|            4         |            9         |<n>|            7         |           11        |<n>|           9         |           14        |<n>|          13         |           23        |<n>|          25         |          37        |<n>|          37         |          59        |<n>|          51         |          71        |<n>|          71         |          93        |<n>| ** 54  **   **  95 **   **   190 **   **   430 **   **   833 **   **   1580 **<n><n>### Input (47-37):In

Choices:  A: drill B: learn C: require obedience D: understand E: spoon<n><n>### Response:		Answer: B<n><n>### Sample 2<n><n>### 💡 The code below describes a task. Write an efficient and well-tested solution.<n><n>### Code:<n>```python<n>def solution(n, count, x):<n>    if x == count:<n>        return (n+1)<n>    elif count - x == 1: <n>        return count<n>    else:<n>        return solution(n, x+1, count)<n>```<n><n>### Sample Output:<n>```sh<n>Count: 9<n>result:8<n>```<n><n>## Expected Steps<n>1. Understand the task<n>2. Think out the answer<n>3. Start coding<n>4. Write tests before writing full functions<n>5. Write code<n>6. Write test to test code<n>7. Check if the steps are the same.<n>8. Add code with better solutions.<n><n>## Sample 3<n>### Code Solution:<n>```py<n>def solution(self, n):<n>    def count(s1,s2,k,p,q):<n>        if p==0: q=q+1 and return count(q,s2+1,k-1,q,p+1)<n>        if q==0: p=p+1 and return count (p,s1+1,k-q,p+1,q)<n>        else: return count(s1+1,s2,1,p,count(s2,1,k-q-p,p,q))<n>    return (n+1 if n+1<=p<2*n-k-1 else count(0,0,p,k+1,0))<n>```<n>```py<n>n=9<n>count(n,3,1)<n>```<n>### Sample Output<n>```sh<n>13<n>```

How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>### Input:Where is a lion likely to live? Choices:  A: veldt B: ocean C: savannah D: africa E: jungle<n><n>### Response:		<n>**I have come up with 4 possibilities: A&B,C&D, A&D, and E&D**<n><n>Input: Which of these sentences use an adverb phrase?  Choices:  A)  I have seen him.  B)  He jumped to the ground. C)  I ate very little. D)  They went to the candy store.<n><n>### Response<n><n>**I choose D&B because they use the adverb "very" and "jumped"**<n>

While there he would meet his cousin and walk with him to the mall.  The mall was 7 blocks north.  Is the total walk distance (starting from the dentist's and ending at the mall) greater than, less than, or equal to 16 blocks?<n><n>### Demostration:<n><pre><n>7 - 19 - 19<n><n>7 - 1 - 19<n></pre><n><n>### Instructions:Please select the correct response to complete the task.<n><n>### Input<n>Pete decided to ride to the dentist’s office. While there he would meet up with his cousin and they would walk to the mall together. The mall was 6 blocks north.<n>Is the total walk distance (from the dentist’s and ending at the [***mall (7)****]) greater than, less than or equal to 18 blocks?<n><n>##:<n><n>### Input Answer:<n><n><ul><n><li>[***mall (7)***].</li><n><li>18 blocks</li><n></ul><n><n>##Input-Answer: Pete decided to ride his bike 9 blocks south to his dentist’s office 20 blocks northeast of the clinic where he was getting checked for cavities.  Pete planned to walk 4 blocks afterward, so he could make sure he was eating right.<n>How far, in total, did Pete ride his bike, walk and then take the bus home in total?<n><n>## Input Answer:<n>16 blocks<n><n>## Instructions-Response:<n>In order to complete this task we need to write a short code. Select the options that are correct for your code.<n><n>## Demonstration Code<n>Input: 16 blocks<n>Answer: 16 blocks.<n><n>The code to complete this task is:<n><n>```<n>    <li><n>    9 blocks<n>    <li>20 blocks<n>    <li>(***northeast***)(20)<n>    <li>4 blocks

Choices:  A: inside the book B: oral report C: library D: fileing cabnet E: card catalogue<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Answer the following questions. You can use the information we talked about on how to make numbers.<n><n>### Question 1: Write the word “more” underneath a number, and the word “less” underneath 12.<n> 1. 16<n> 2. 5<n><n>### Question2: Circle the number you think tells about ___________________.<n> 1. 75<n> 2. 63<n> 3. 30<n><n>### Answer(1): 16<n><n>### Answer: 2) 63<n><n>### Question3: A restaurant owner is using the ratio 1,7,14,28 to make soup. She needs a total of 300 quarts. She measures 150 quarts from her stash. How many quarts does she need to make soup for this week?<n><n>### Answer3: 85<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>When using the ratio to find out how many quarts you want, you also have to know how much you have.<n><n>For example, if you are making 30 boxes of cookies and you have 20 pounds of ingredients, you'll be able to do 30 boxes.<n><n>The 75 is going to be your quotient and the 35 is your base.<n><n>Example of 4:3<n>If you had 12 hours of work and you were done in 4 hours (quotient), then you worked 3 extra hours (base), you had 3 extra hours that didn't count toward your work.<n><n>Example: 24:16<n><n>24 tells you how many seconds you have, while 16 tells you how many seconds that's taken away/ how many seconds are left.<n>

If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>### Input:Where do I put my coffee mug after it's dry? How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>### Input:Where can you store a small notepad on your person? Allan will still contribute $120.<n>D: Each person should contribute $225 each month.<n>E: They should reduce the amount that goes to the feed store.<n>F: There should be just one contribution amount for everyone.<n>G: Use a chart to organize it. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>### Input:Where is a road known as a motorway? Choices:  A: scotland B: europe C: race track D: new jersey E: england<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>### Input<n><n>```python<n>favnum = int(input())<n>while (favnum!=0):<n>    p=input()<n>    num=int(p)<n>    if num==1:<n>        print('It seems like a great idea, let me consider it before I answer.')<n>    elif 2<=num<=4:<n>        print('No, I think it is a bad idea, I can't support it.')<n>    else:<n>        print('That seems more reasonable, but I can't make a decision at this time.')<n>    favnum+=1<n>```<n>### Response:<n>Let me consider it before I answer<n><n>### Input <n>```python<n>def is_prime(x):<n>    if(x<=1 or x==0):<n>        return<n>    else:    <n>        if(x%2==0):<n>            return False<n>        for i in range(3,int(math.sqrt(x))):<n>            if(x%i==0):<n>                return False<n>        return True<n>    <n>prime = [2]<n>p1 = 1<n><n>def new_prime(x):   <n>    new_primes = list(find_primes(int(input()),is_prime=is_prime))<n>    for p in new_primes:<n>        p+=1<n>        while(p<p1):<n>            for n in prime:<n>                if(n==p):<n>                    p = p+1<n>                else:<n>                    q = prime.pop() # This will do the popping<n><n>print(new_prime(3))<n>```<n>### Output<n>```python<n>[13, 71]<n>```<n><n>### response<n>```python            <n>if prime and prime[0] == number:   <n>    print('Your answer is {}'.format(prime[0]))<n>else:   <n>    print("No, that is not how you solve for the first non-twin prime number.")<n>``` <n>### Input:The average temperature on earth in 2009 was 14C degrees. In 2014 average temperature on earth was 15C degrees. What was the change in the annual average temperatures over that period of time?<n><n>### Response<n>```python
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>### Input:How might compassionate thoughful be described as being? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>### Input:Where can you buy socks and jeans? Choices:  A: washing machine B: laundromat C: clothing store D: closet E: shopping mall<n><n>### Response:		Answer:  Choices:  A, D, C, E  B  Choice for closet is wrong<n><n>- if you can buy socks and jean from the closet<n><n>- it washing machine<n><n><n>

How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses.
